title: Veterans See Costs and Risks in Hegseth’s Military Rewind to 1990
summary: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth has identified real problems, veteran officers say, but by looking back 35 years for policy cues, he risks hurting, not helping, military readiness.

title: Why Pete Hegseth Summoned Top Military Leaders
summary: Secretary of Defense Pete Hegseth faced a room of hundreds of generals and admirals whom he had summoned from across the globe, and made his case for shaking up a force that he said had gone soft and “woke.” Greg Jaffe, the Pentagon reporter for The New York Times, discusses Hegseth’s speech.

title: What Women Heard in Hegseth’s Remarks About Physical Standards
summary: The defense secretary raised the issue suggesting women were getting into combat not because they met high standards, but because they were given a pass.

title: Trump Asked Universities to Sign a Compact. Some See a Trap.
summary: Trump officials want universities to sign on to conservative priorities to get special treatment. Some in higher education say agreeing would end academic freedom.

title: Apple Takes Down ICE Tracking Apps Amid Trump Pressure Campaign
summary: Trump administration officials have issued several legal threats over ICEBlock, a popular app that allows users to alert others to the presence of nearby immigration agents.

title: Kennedy Fires N.I.H. Scientist Who Filed Whistle-Blower Complaint
summary: Dr. Jeanne Marrazzo, who was on administrative leave, alleged that the Trump administration had defied court orders and undermined vaccine research.

title: After Trump Pulls Funding, Work Continues on N.Y. Area Transit Projects
summary: Two of the largest infrastructure initiatives in the United States were still moving forward this week despite the battles over a government shutdown surrounding them.

title: Partisan Language Inserted Into Education Dept. Workers’ Automated Emails
summary: The out-of-office responses from the accounts of employees on furlough cast blame for the shutdown on Democrats.

title: A Government Shutdown Silver Lining: Federal Workers Eat and Drink at a Discount
summary: Washington watering holes and restaurants are showing solidarity and seizing an opportunity to draw in out-of-work government employees.

title: FDA Approves Generic Version of Abortion Pill Mifepristone
summary: The decision enraged opponents of abortion, who have been pressuring the Trump administration to restrict access to abortion medication.

title: On ‘The Life of a Showgirl,’ Taylor Swift Has a Lust for Love (and Her Foes)
summary: On her 12th original album, the pop superstar sounds hungry to embrace her future — but not until she attends to some unfinished business.

title: Taylor Swift Wears Bob Mackie’s Bejeweled Designs for ‘Life of a Showgirl’
summary: Bob Mackie, whose bejeweled designs have appeared on a list of performers that now includes the singer, reflects on a role he has dressed many for.

title: Sean ‘Diddy’ Combs Asks Judge for Mercy: ‘I Lost My Way’
summary: The music mogul submitted a letter to the court ahead of his sentencing on Friday for his conviction on two prostitution-related counts.

title: After Declining to Give Trump a Sword for King Charles, a Museum Leader Is Out
summary: The departure of Todd Arrington, who led the Dwight D. Eisenhower Presidential Library and Museum, came after the administration sought a sword from its collection as a gift for King Charles.

title: Deadly Car Ramming and Stabbing Outside UK Synagogue Is Declared Terrorist Attack
summary: The police identified the attacker as Jihad al-Shamie, 35, a British citizen of Syrian descent. He was shot dead, the police said, after killing two people in Manchester, England.

title: Manchester Synagogue Attack Fuels Fears of Antisemitism in Britain
summary: In the hours after an attack, a blanket of fear and grief fell over synagogues and Jewish community centers across the country.

title: As Russian Drones Menace Europe, Putin Says Moscow Has No Plans to Invade
summary: President Vladimir V. Putin lashed out at “European elites” for “whipping up the hysteria” about the “Russian threat.”

title: OpenAI’s Sora Video App Is Jaw-Dropping (for Better and Worse)
summary: Sora, OpenAI’s new video-generating app, is really a social network in disguise that can bring creative A.I. to the masses — and its problems, too.

title: A.I. Is Driving a Stock Market Rally in China, Too
summary: Surging interest in artificial intelligence is generating huge gains for Chinese tech stocks like Alibaba, which has more than doubled this year.

title: Madagascar’s President Rajoelina Dissolved His Government, but Calls for His Resignation Continue
summary: A growing protest movement on the African island, despite deadly clashes with security forces, vows to keep fighting until Andry Rajoelina is ousted.

title: This City Was Forced to Overhaul Its Police Department. Crime Plummeted.
summary: A federal judge said she was prepared to release Newark from a 2016 consent decree imposed after investigators found the city’s police routinely used excessive force and conducted unconstitutional stops and searches.

title: Trump’s ‘Compact’ With Universities Is Just Extortion
summary: There seems to be no limit to the president’s odious attempts to control higher education.

title: Taylor Swift Is No Showgirl
summary: Once you’re a showgirl, you’ll never be anyone’s girl next door again.

title: American Soldiers in American Cities
summary: Our Pentagon reporter explains how President Trump has tapped into a fear that resonates in many places around the world.

title: Tesla Is Sued by Family Who Says Faulty Cybertruck Doors Led to Woman’s Death
summary: A college student was trapped in a burning Cybertruck because electronic doors made it difficult for her to get out or be rescued, a lawsuit claims.

title: The Big Bad Wolf Is Afraid of You
summary: Researchers found that the predatory canines were far more likely to flee recordings of human voices than they were to run away from other sounds.

title: Paramount Nears a Deal to Buy Bari Weiss’s Free Press
summary: Ms. Weiss, a co-founder of the site, would become editor in chief of CBS News, people briefed on the talks said.

title: Texas Megachurch Pastor Pleads Guilty to Child Sex Abuse
summary: Robert Morris, the founder of Gateway Church, which has one of the nation’s largest congregations, admitted to sexually abusing a child in the 1980s.
